caption: Figure 1: Left: Overview of our method BGE. In typical CCSSL methods, the inter-task data pairs are incomparable. We employ an external dataset to complement these missing comparisons, effectively bridging the inter-task gap. Right: t-SNE [47] visualization of four classes belonging to different tasks in continual learning. Compared to prior methods Fine-tune and CaSSLe [16], we make the inter-task data more separable.
description: The figure illustrates the proposed method BGE, which bridges the inter-task gap in Continual Contrastive Self-Supervised Learning (CCSSL) using external data. The left panel shows a schematic of how BGE works by incorporating external data into the contrastive learning process to compare data from different tasks, unlike traditional methods where inter-task data are considered incomparable. The right panel presents t-SNE visualizations of four classes belonging to different tasks, demonstrating that BGE improves the separability of inter-task data compared to existing methods (Fine-tune and CaSSLe).

caption: Figure 2: Performance improvement of BGE at CIFAR100 100 tasks setting. Bold indicates better performance.
description: This figure shows the accuracy of three continual self-supervised learning methods (FT, CaSSLe, and PFR) with and without the proposed method (BGE) across 100 tasks on the CIFAR-100 dataset.  The x-axis represents the number of tasks, and the y-axis represents the accuracy.  The lines show that for all three methods, the accuracy is significantly improved by the application of BGE.

caption: Figure 3: FID score of different sampling algorithms when CIFAR and CPI as external data.
description: This figure shows Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) scores comparing random and OPO sampling algorithms under different external dataset compositions (CIFAR and CPI).  Lower FID scores indicate better similarity between the in-task and external datasets.  The results show that OPO sampling significantly improves the similarity when the external data contain out-of-distribution (OOD) data (CPI), highlighting its effectiveness in selecting relevant and diverse samples.

caption: Figure 4: Comparison of external data sampled by different algorithms. When the entire external data quality is high (CIFAR), there is little difference between random and OPO sampling. When the data contains many OOD data (CPI), OPO outperforms random in sampling relevant and diverse samples.
description: This figure compares the results of two sampling methods, random and OPO, on two different external datasets, CIFAR10 and CPI.  The visualizations show the distribution of in-task data points and sampled external data points in a 2D embedding space. When using CIFAR10 (high-quality, in-distribution data), both methods produce similar results.  However, when using CPI (containing out-of-distribution data), the OPO method shows a more desirable distribution, better representing the in-task data.
